content.source_1: Phil Zuckerman (2008), Society Without God: What the Least Religious Nations Can Tell Us About Contentment, New York University Press — Ethnographic evidence from highly secular Denmark and Sweden shows high social trust, strong social safety nets, low crime, and high life satisfaction, suggesting religion is not required for a well-functioning, content society.
content.source_2: Tyler J. VanderWeele, Shanshan Li, et al. (2016), “Religious Service Attendance and Mortality Among Women,” JAMA Internal Medicine 176(6):777–785 — A large US cohort study (N≈74,000) found frequent religious service attendance was associated with substantially lower all-cause mortality, indicating religion can confer measurable health benefits, challenging the idea that it is unnecessary for wellbeing.
content.source_3: Ara Norenzayan (2013), Big Gods: How Religion Transformed Cooperation and Conflict, Princeton University Press — Proposes that belief in moralizing, watchful deities historically promoted large-scale cooperation when formal institutions were weak; as modern secular institutions (courts, policing) strengthen, religion becomes less necessary for social order.
content.source_4: Pew Research Center (2021), “What Makes Life Meaningful? Views From 17 Advanced Economies” — Survey data show people most commonly cite family, friends, work, and material stability as sources of meaning, with religion ranking low in many wealthy countries, indicating many derive life meaning without religion.
content.source_5: United Nations (1948), Universal Declaration of Human Rights — A globally endorsed ethical framework articulated in secular, universal terms and not grounded in any single religious tradition, demonstrating that shared moral norms and rights can be established without religious foundations.
content.source_6: Robert D. Putnam and David E. Campbell (2010), American Grace: How Religion Divides and Unites Us, Simon & Schuster — Using extensive survey data, the authors find religious involvement correlates with higher volunteering, charitable giving (including to nonreligious causes), and dense social networks, suggesting religion plays a distinctive role in generating social capital.
